title: 113_s1507
content: The "Tribal General Welfare Exclusion Act of 2013" may be cited as the Act. It amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 by inserting a new section regarding Indian general welfare benefits. The "Tribal General Welfare Exclusion Act of 2013" establishes that gross income does not include Indian general welfare benefits, defined as payments or services provided to members of Indian tribes under specific guidelines for the promotion of general welfare, without favoritism towards tribal leaders and not as compensation for services. The "Tribal General Welfare Exclusion Act of 2013" defines terms such as Indian tribal government, dependent, and lavish or extravagant for the purpose of excluding Indian general welfare benefits from gross income. The Tribal General Welfare Exclusion Act of 2013 establishes guidelines for defining lavish or extravagant benefits in Indian tribal government programs, including provisions for ceremonial activities and cultural significance. The Tribal General Welfare Exclusion Act of 2013 establishes guidelines for Indian tribal government programs to benefit the general welfare of the tribal community, with deference given to Indian tribal governments for program administration. The amendments made by this Act apply to taxable years with unexpired refund limitations under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Refund or credit of overpayment attributable to amendments may be allowed within 1-year period from enactment of the Act if claim is filed before the close of the period. SEC. 3. TRIBAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE. The Secretary of the Treasury establishes a Tribal Advisory Committee to advise on taxation matters related to Indians. The Committee also assists in providing training and education for internal revenue field agents regarding Federal Indian law and the unique legal relationship with Indian tribal governments. The Tribal Advisory Committee is established to advise on taxation matters related to Indians and provide training to tribal financial officers on the implementation of the Act. The Committee consists of 7 members appointed by various entities for 4-year terms. The Tribal Advisory Committee consists of 7 members appointed for 4-year terms, with initial appointments staggered for 2 years. SEC. 4. OTHER RELIEF FOR INDIAN TRIBES. The Secretary of the Treasury will suspend audits and examinations of Indian tribal governments and members related to the general welfare exclusion until prescribed education and training is completed. The running of limitations under the Internal Revenue Code will be suspended during this period. The Secretary may also waive penalties and interest for Indian tribal governments or members. The legislation suspends audits and examinations of Indian tribal governments and members regarding the general welfare exclusion. Definitions for Indian tribal government and Indian tribe are provided in the subsection.
